cover_slide_data.heading: Welcome on board - Devops Team
cover_slide_data.intro: This Course will help you in your first steps in DevOps Team.

cover_slide_data.heading: Welcome on board - Devops Team
cover_slide_data.intro: This Course will help you in your first steps in DevOps Team.

published_attributes.title: Milestone 1
published_attributes.serialized_body:
MILESTONE 1

Milestone 1 is intended to configure basic, non-technical stuff and show you DevOps Team in Netguru way of working. Tasks in this part are planned for your second onboarding day

blocks.text: MILESTONE 1

  show you DevOps Team in Netguru way of working. Tasks in this part are 
                          planned for your second onboarding day

published_attributes.title: Who we are?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What is a Team structure?

Let's start from the beginning! Look at our DevOps Confluence main page. Here you can meet your new teammates. Moreover, on this page you can find plenty of useful information and hints for DevOps -> so add this page to your bookmarks and jump to next slide!

blocks.text: What is a Team structure?

Let's start from the beginning! Look at our DevOps Confluence main page. 

Here you can meet your new teammates. Moreover, on this page you can find plenty of useful information and hints for DevOps -> so add this page to your bookmarks and jump to next slide!

published_attributes.title: Task 1 - main DevOps page update
published_attributes.serialized_body: It's pretty fast, but it's good time to start with your first warm up task in DevOps Team! :) Add yourself as a new team member* -> here**. Open file with diagrams.net -> add yourself -> save -> update diagram on main DevOps Confluence page -> and now officially - Welcome on board! We are glad and excited that we have you with us! * Ask your mentor if list of member is up to date - maybe you can do some cleanup? ** Ask your mentor if you don't have access to drive.

blocks.text:
It's pretty fast, but it's good time to start with your first warm up task  in DevOps Team! :)

Add yourself as a new team member* -> here**.

Open file with diagrams.net -> add yourself -> save -> update diagram on main DevOps Confluence page -> and now officially - Welcome on board! We are glad and excited that we have you with us!




* Ask your mentor if list of member is up to date - maybe you can do some cleanup?
** Ask your mentor if you don't have access to drive.

published_attributes.title: Task 2 - Source app update
published_attributes.serialized_body: Source app is the Netguru Salesforce powered ecosystem allowing instant access to the company, project, and team data. Based on your personal data it is possible to better match you to project. Add your data to an App. Be sure that you added your both - Skills and Bio data to Source app.

blocks.text:
Source app is the Netguru Salesforce powered ecosystem allowing instant access to the company, project, and team data. Based on your personal data it is possible to better match you to project. 

Add your data to an App. Be sure that you added your both - Skills and Bio data to Source app.

published_attributes.title: Task 4 - Office Card Number
published_attributes.serialized_body: If you plan to visit the Office in your city -> Complete the Office Card Number form, otherwise if you don't plan to visit office, or you work 100% remote you can skip this point. Please remember that you can back and request Office Card whenever you will need.

published_attributes.title: Task 6 - Vat tax whitelist [B2B only]
published_attributes.serialized_body: If you are on a b2b contract -> make sure that you are on VAT tax whitelist. Otherwise, if you are not on a b2b conctrat or you are on a VAT whitelist - skip this step

published_attributes.title: Get familiar with your MacOS
published_attributes.serialized_body: If those are your first steps in MacOS world, it's worth to get familiar with some tips and useful apps. - MacOS tips - Take a look at the Trackpad tutorial to get familiar with super powerful gestures - press ⌘ + space => the Spotlight Search will pop up, type Trackpad there and open its preferences window with some nice instructions - APFS (the default filesystem) is available in case-sensitive and case-insensitive variants on macOS, with case-insensitive being the default - Mac comes with plenty of software available out of the box (HINT: the CLI tools are not GNU software, make sure you understand what's the difference) - There is no native package manager as we know (think of apt / yum), to get some utils installed use either: - Disk Images (.dmg files); they're easy to use once you get how they work. The .dmg file (can be compared to some sort of an .iso file) is the actual file that contains all the data. When you double click the .dmg file, it mounts a "virtual" disk to your desktop - pip ($ sudo easy_install pip) for python packages [like ansible for example] - brew for everything else [like tmux for example] Useful tools: - Muzzle - bear - Karabiner - Bartender - Flux - Todolist - Omnifocus - Pullreminders - Trello - Notion

blocks.text:
If those are your first steps in MacOS world, it's worth to get familiar with some tips and useful apps.


- MacOS tips
- Take a look at the Trackpad tutorial to get familiar with super powerful gestures
- press ⌘ + space => the Spotlight Search will pop up, type Trackpad there and open its preferences window with some nice instructions
- APFS (the default filesystem) is available in case-sensitive and case-insensitive variants on macOS, with case-insensitive being the default
- Mac comes with plenty of software available out of the box (HINT: the CLI tools are not GNU software, make sure you understand what's the difference)
- There is no native package manager as we know (think of apt / yum), to get some utils installed use either:
  - Disk Images (.dmg files); they're easy to use once you get how they work. The .dmg file (can be compared to some sort of an .iso file) is the actual file that contains all the data. When you double click the .dmg file, it mounts a "virtual" disk to your desktop
  - pip ($ sudo easy_install pip) for python packages [like ansible for example]
  - brew for everything else [like tmux for example]


Useful tools:
  - Muzzle
  - bear
  - Karabiner
  - Bartender
  - Flux
  - Todolist
  - Omnifocus
  - Pullreminders
  - Trello
  - Notion

draft_attributes.title: Get familiar with your MacOS
draft_attributes.serialized_body: If those are your first steps in MacOS world, it's worth to get familiar with some tips and useful apps. - MacOS tips - Take a look at the Trackpad tutorial to get familiar with super powerful gestures - press ⌘ + space => the Spotlight Search will pop up, type Trackpad there and open its preferences window with some nice instructions - APFS (the default filesystem) is available in case-sensitive and case-insensitive variants on macOS, with case-insensitive being the default - Mac comes with plenty of software available out of the box (HINT: the CLI tools are not GNU software, make sure you understand what's the difference) - There is no native package manager as we know (think of apt / yum), to get some utils installed use either: - Disk Images (.dmg files); they're easy to use once you get how they work. The .dmg file (can be compared to some sort of an .iso file) is the actual file that contains all the data. When you double click the .dmg file, it mounts a "virtual" disk to your desktop - pip ($ sudo easy_install pip) for python packages [like ansible for example] - brew for everything else [like tmux for example] Useful tools: - Muzzle - bear - Karabiner - Bartender - Flux - Todolist - Omnifocus - Pullreminders - Trello - Notion

blocks.text:
If those are your first steps in MacOS world, it's worth to get familiar with some tips and useful apps.


- MacOS tips
- Take a look at the Trackpad tutorial to get familiar with super powerful gestures
- press ⌘ + space => the Spotlight Search will pop up, type Trackpad there and open its preferences window with some nice instructions
- APFS (the default filesystem) is available in case-sensitive and case-insensitive variants on macOS, with case-insensitive being the default
- Mac comes with plenty of software available out of the box (HINT: the CLI tools are not GNU software, make sure you understand what's the difference)
- There is no native package manager as we know (think of apt / yum), to get some utils installed use either:
  - Disk Images (.dmg files); they're easy to use once you get how they work. The .dmg file (can be compared to some sort of an .iso file) is the actual file that contains all the data. When you double click the .dmg file, it mounts a "virtual" disk to your desktop
  - pip ($ sudo easy_install pip) for python packages [like ansible for example]
  - brew for everything else [like tmux for example]


Useful tools:
  - Muzzle
  - bear
  - Karabiner
  - Bartender
  - Flux
  - Todolist
  - Omnifocus
  - Pullreminders
  - Trello
  - Notion

published_attributes.title: DevOps toolset - part1
published_attributes.serialized_body: Below you can see list of tools used across entire Netguru company. We, DevOps Team, use those tools daily basics as well, so take a look and get familiar with them. - Slack -communicator in Netguru - you will have dedicated meeting how to use slack and communicate in efficient way. Channels structure/Channels that you should be interested in: - #client-*client_name*  - (Slack Public channel) used to communicate directly with the client - #project-*project_name* - (Slack Public channel) used to communicate with the Netguru project team (clients are not allowed here) - #notify-*project_name* - (Slack Public channel) - used to send receive notifications from various tour - #biz-*project_name* - (Slack Private channel) - used mostly by PM, leader, CS, BD, Core - #opp-*project_name* - (Opportunity Public or Private channel) - for new bid/project - #devops-internal - all DevOps internal communication - main Team channel - #devops - channel where everyone from company can ask about DevOps related issue/problem/question - ninja/secondary* is responsible to react on activity on this channel - #devops-info - notifications from Jira service desks and monitoring tools - ninja/secondary* is responsible to react on activity on this channel - #devops-mentoring - do you have any question? don't hesitate to ask other DevOps! - it will be good if you can help with someone questions too - #support-security-devops - security related concerns/issues can be raised here - other useful channels - get familiar with Kudos app - 1Password -- if you've never used this sort of tool, start immediately, you'll thank yourself later, read the instruction: - it is important to keep all your secrets encrypted in 1Password - Store your personal data/passwords in the Private vault - Remember to always use random generated secure password - Remember to use MFA always whenever it is possible (you can use Authy, Google authenticator mobile app as your virtual MFA device) - Chrome extension will make it easier to user 1Password vault - Chrome - preferred web browser - G Suite - there's no need to configure Mac native Calendar/Mail etc, web apps are easy to start with - Toggle track - get familiar with this guide - be sure that you know what is billable vs non billable * You don't know what ninja/secondary means? - it is described on next slides.

blocks.text:
Below you can see list of tools used across entire Netguru company. We, DevOps Team, use those tools daily basics as well, so take a look and get familiar with them.

  - Slack -communicator in Netguru - you will have dedicated meeting how to use slack and communicate in efficient way.
Channels structure/Channels that you should be interested in:
    - #client-*client_name*  - (Slack Public channel) used to communicate directly with the client
    - #project-*project_name* - (Slack Public channel) used to communicate with the Netguru project team (clients are not allowed here) 
    - #notify-*project_name* - (Slack Public channel) - used to send receive notifications from various tour
    - #biz-*project_name* - (Slack Private channel) - used mostly by PM, leader, CS, BD, Core
    - #opp-*project_name* - (Opportunity Public or Private channel) - for new bid/project
    - #devops-internal - all DevOps internal communication - main Team channel
    - #devops - channel where everyone from company can ask about DevOps related issue/problem/question - ninja/secondary* is responsible to react on activity on this channel
    - #devops-info - notifications from Jira service desks and monitoring tools - ninja/secondary* is responsible to react on activity on this channel
    - #devops-mentoring - do you have any question? don't hesitate to ask other DevOps! - it will be good if you can help with someone questions too
    - #support-security-devops - security related concerns/issues can be raised here
   - other useful channels
   - get familiar with Kudos app

  - 1Password -- if you've never used this sort of tool, start immediately, you'll thank yourself later, read the instruction:
     - it is important to keep all your secrets encrypted in 1Password
     - Store your personal data/passwords in the Private vault
     - Remember to always use random generated secure password
     - Remember to use MFA always whenever it is possible (you can use Authy, Google authenticator mobile app as your virtual MFA device) 
     - Chrome extension will make it easier to user 1Password vault

  - Chrome - preferred web browser

  - G Suite - there's no need to configure Mac native Calendar/Mail etc, web apps are easy to start with

  - Toggle track - get familiar with this guide - be sure that you know what is billable vs non billable 

  
* You don't know what ninja/secondary means? - it is described on next slides.

    - #biz-*project_name* - (Slack Private channel) - used mostly by PM, leader, CS, BD, Core

Be sure that you know how Slack mentions like @channel, @here, @group work

published_attributes.title: JIRA/Conf
published_attributes.serialized_body: Jira and Confluence are Attlasian tools for project management and Wiki/documentations. Confluence Confluence is a company internal tool only. No one outside the organisation should have access to it. Consider it wiki/company intranet. Links: - main Netguru confluence space - DevOps space You can stop for a moment here and look around two above linked Confluence spaces. You can find plenty useful information about organization, technical documentation etc Jira Jira is task management tool. Jira can be accessed by 3rd parties and customers to collaborate on particular projects. Links: - DevOps desk - service desks for DevOps request, a place where Netgurals can raise an issue, question against DevOps Team - ninja/secondary* is responsible to handle tickets - DevOps Kanban Board - place where all DevOps team members tickets and activities are tracked This one can be helpful for you in future - advanced Jira usage * You don't know what ninja/secondary means? - it is described on next slides.

blocks.text:
Jira and Confluence are Attlasian tools for project management and Wiki/documentations.


Confluence
Confluence is a company internal tool only. No one outside the organisation should have access to it. Consider it wiki/company intranet.
Links:
 - main Netguru confluence space
 - DevOps space

You can stop for a moment here and look around two above linked Confluence spaces. You can find plenty useful information about organization, technical documentation etc



Jira
Jira is task management tool. Jira can be accessed by 3rd parties and customers to collaborate on particular projects.
Links:
- DevOps desk - service desks for DevOps request, a place where Netgurals can raise an issue, question against DevOps Team - ninja/secondary* is responsible to handle tickets
- DevOps Kanban Board - place where all DevOps team members tickets and activities are tracked

This one can be helpful for you in future - advanced Jira usage


* You don't know what ninja/secondary means? - it is described on next slides.

blocks.text:
Jira and Confluence are Attlasian tools for project management and Wiki/documentations.


Confluence
Confluence is a company internal tool only. No one outside the organisation should have access to it. Consider it wiki/company intranet.
Links:
 - main Netguru confluence space
 - DevOps space

You can stop for a moment here and look around two above linked Confluence spaces. You can find plenty useful information about organization, technical documentation etc



Jira
Jira is task management tool. Jira can be accessed by 3rd parties and customers to collaborate on particular projects.
Links:
- DevOps desk - service desks for DevOps request, a place where Netgurals can raise an issue, question against DevOps Team - ninja/secondary* is responsible to handle tickets
- DevOps Kanban Board - place where all DevOps team members tickets and activities are tracked

This one can be helpful for you in future - advanced Jira usage


* You don't know what ninja/secondary means? - it is described on next slides.

published_attributes.title: Task 10 - Create blogpost
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Now, when you know how we use Jira/Confluence perform following 3 tasks:

- you should definitely add Jira/Confluence links from previous slide to your bookmark - create your first blogpost in team Space on Confluence - let others know that you are new DevOps on board!(Pay attention to select Blog post instead of Page!!!) - create your introduction task in our DevOps Jira project - instruction can help you. Ticket title can be: newbie onboarding

blocks.text: Now, when you know how we use Jira/Confluence perform following 3 tasks:

- you should definitely add Jira/Confluence links from previous slide to your bookmark

- create your first blogpost in team Space on Confluence - let others know that you are new DevOps on board!(Pay attention to select Blog post instead of Page!!!)

- create your introduction task in our DevOps Jira project - instruction can help you. Ticket title can be: newbie onboarding

published_attributes.title: DevOps service desk roles
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Roles in DevOps team are assigned to engineers on weekly basis. Decision day is Friday. „Bob The Bot" informs other teams about DevOps role assignments every morning on #devops slack channel. It can possibly be used on other channels i.e. to inform particular client/team about. Secondary – covers all short tickets - less than 4h to resolution (also known as “tickets”) Ninja – focuses on monitoring the  #devops slack channel, responsible for the fastest possible response time, triaging tickets and projects (deciding if they are tickets or projects <4h or >4h, filling missing ticket information i.e. additional communication with developers/project managers). One protects engineers against any direct  communication or other distractions. Ninja also resolves arguments about work being billable or not, assigns ticket to Secondary, decides about priority and decreases it if required (triaging process). This role can be in fact very busy. Currently because of reduced number of tickets Secondary and Ninja roles are CONNECTED(one person)!!!!!

Tickets SLO and triaging - link. * Role not is use: Primary – this role is responsible for immediate responding to any fires/blockers. If there is no fires he/she takes PID role. This role is also connected with 24/7 oncall and responding to out of hours fires on a given week. Currently we don't have a need to keep this role in DevOps Team. ** More info about our team roles as well as best practices can be found here

Ninja also resolves arguments about work being billable or not, assigns ticket to Secondary, decides about priority and decreases it if required (triaging process). * Role not is use:
Primary – this role is responsible for immediate responding to any fires/blockers. If there is no fires he/she takes PID role. This role is also connected with 24/7 oncall and responding to out of hours fires on a given week. Currently we don't have a need to keep this role in DevOps Team.

** More info about our team roles as well as best practices can be found here

published_attributes.title: Leaders and feedback meeting
published_attributes.serialized_body: O3: Our weekly or bi-weekly one-on-one meetings with the team leader. Thanks to these we can build a better relationship with the leader - Provide and receive most recent feedback - Discuss your goals and their current progress - Discuss all recent challenges F2F (Face to Face) Every quarter every person in our team is meeting with a leader to discuss achievements from previous quarter and plan goals for the upcoming one. The goal of f2f meeting is to plan, give and get feedback. Every second quarter we talk about salary rise. More info here

blocks.text:
O3:
Our weekly or bi-weekly one-on-one meetings with the team leader. 
Thanks to these we can build a better relationship with the leader
  - Provide and receive most recent feedback
  - Discuss your goals and their current progress
  - Discuss all recent challenges

F2F (Face to Face) 
Every quarter every person in our team is meeting with a leader to discuss achievements from previous quarter and plan goals for the upcoming one. The goal of f2f meeting is to plan, give and get feedback. Every second quarter we talk about salary rise.


More info here

published_attributes.title: OKR
published_attributes.serialized_body: OKR is Objectives and Key Results. It is a goal system used by Google and others. It is a simple tool to create alignment and engagement around measurable goals. More info you can find on Netguru OKR

blocks.text:
OKR is Objectives and Key Results. It is a goal system used by Google and others. It is a simple tool to create alignment and engagement around measurable goals.

More info you can find on Netguru OKR

published_attributes.title: What tools do we use?
published_attributes.serialized_body: We are sure that you are wondering which technologies you will be using daily basis - take a look on below list. Cloud providers and main services: - AWS* - EC2 - VPC - Redis - RDS - ELB - ECS - IAM - CodeDeploy - ACM - Route53 - CloudFront - S3 - Azure - GCP Tools: - Docker(with docker-compose) - Terraform - GitHub - CircleCi - Linux - sops - pre-commit * We use terraform modules repo to configure AWS services - you can take a look on them and add repo to your bookmarks.

blocks.text:
We are sure that you are wondering which technologies you will be using daily basis - take a look on below list. 
 
Cloud providers and main services:
- AWS*
     - EC2
     - VPC
     - Redis
     - RDS
     - ELB
     - ECS
     - IAM
     - CodeDeploy
     - ACM
     - Route53
     - CloudFront
     - S3
- Azure
- GCP

Tools:
 - Docker(with docker-compose)
 - Terraform
 - GitHub
 - CircleCi
 - Linux
 - sops
 - pre-commit

* We use terraform modules repo to configure AWS services - you can take a look on them and add repo to your bookmarks.

published_attributes.title: Task 11 - Configure environment
published_attributes.serialized_body: Below you can see list of tools that we use in DevOps team daily basics. Take a look, read, choose, install and get familiar with them. Tools that can make your live with code easier and more effective: - rbenv and tfenv/tfswitch – install those tools to easily manage different versions of respectively Ruby and Terraform in your local environment. Must-have! - IDE: - nano, VIM, Emacs, Neovim - Atom (Atom is a free and open-source text and source code editor for macOS, Linux, and Microsoft Windows with support for plug-ins written in Node.js, and embedded Git Control, developed by GitHub. Atom is a desktop application built using web technologies) - Visual Studio Code (preferred)/ VSCodium (if you're a F[L]OSS enthusiast) - sublime text 3 - onivim - Terminal: - tmux - iTerm2 - Terminal.app (available out of the box)? - Zsh – if it's not the default shell on your Mac – install it and at least try few configurations. It may greatly improve your productivity in comparison - ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh - pretty ZSH with lots of productivity improvements - brew - package manager for macos(like yum/apt in linux)

blocks.text:
Below you can see list of tools that we use in DevOps team daily basics. Take a look, read, choose, install and get familiar with them.

 Tools that can make your live with code easier and more effective:
  
  - rbenv and tfenv/tfswitch – install those tools to easily manage different versions of respectively Ruby and Terraform in your local environment. Must-have! 

  - IDE:
    -  nano, VIM, Emacs, Neovim
    - Atom (Atom is a free and open-source text and source code editor for macOS, Linux, and Microsoft Windows with support for plug-ins written in Node.js, and embedded Git Control, developed by GitHub. Atom is a desktop application built using web technologies)
    - Visual Studio Code (preferred)/ VSCodium (if you're a F[L]OSS enthusiast)
    - sublime text 3
    - onivim

  - Terminal: 
     - tmux
     - iTerm2
     - Terminal.app (available out of the box)?
     - Zsh – if it's not the default shell on your Mac – install it and at least try few configurations. It may greatly improve your productivity in comparison    
     - ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh  - pretty ZSH with lots of productivity improvements
     - brew - package manager for macos(like yum/apt in linux)

Atom is a desktop application built using web technologies) - Visual Studio Code (preferred)/ VSCodium (if you're a F[L]OSS enthusiast) - sublime text 3 - onivim - Terminal: - tmux - iTerm2 - Terminal.app (available out of the box)? - Zsh – if it's not the default shell on your Mac – install it and at least try few configurations. published_attributes.title: Task 12 - Configure github
published_attributes.serialized_body: When you have already known which tools we use you can configure one of them - GitHub: - enable MFA - Make sure you have access to the Netguru organization on Github* - Make sure that you set your name on GitHub account ((can be John D. for example, but not only the nickname) - add ssh key to your account - enable - comit signing - Make sure that github account doesn’t watch automatically repos * if you don't - ask your mentor

blocks.text:
When you have already known which tools we use you can configure one of them - GitHub:

- enable MFA
- Make sure you have access to the Netguru organization on Github*
- Make sure that you set your name on GitHub account ((can be John D. for example, but not only the nickname)
- add ssh key to your account
- enable - comit signing
- Make sure that github account doesn’t watch automatically repos



* if you don't - ask your mentor

blocks.text:
When you have already known which tools we use you can configure one of them - GitHub:

- enable MFA
- Make sure you have access to the Netguru organization on Github*
- Make sure that you set your name on GitHub account ((can be John D. for example, but not only the nickname)
- add ssh key to your account
- enable - comit signing
- Make sure that github account doesn’t watch automatically repos



* if you don't - ask your mentor

published_attributes.title: Task 13 - Configure AWS
published_attributes.serialized_body: Now it's time to configure your AWS account: - before you will do nexts steps ask your mentor to create dedicated AWS account for you! - enable MFA on your AWS account - install AWS google chrome extensions: - AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that is basically essential when working with AWS. This plugin allows you to keep all your assume roles in Chorme extension - by default AWS allows to keep last 5 roles - sync AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that allows to sync assume roles from time to time - details - install aws-cli - to 'talk' with AWS services from your terminal - install aws-vault - during one of your next onboarding day you will see 'Netguru way' for managing access and secret AWS key - recommended solution is AWS-vault. You can install it and configure to use aws-cli with your new created aws account via aws-vault instead of traditional aws/credentials file. Introduction video how it works

blocks.text:
Now it's time to configure your AWS account:

- before you will do nexts steps ask your mentor to create dedicated AWS account for you!

- enable MFA on your AWS account

- install AWS google chrome extensions:
  - AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that is basically essential when working with AWS. This plugin allows you to keep all your assume roles in Chorme extension - by default AWS allows to keep last 5 roles
  - sync AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that allows to sync assume roles from time to time - details

- install aws-cli - to 'talk' with AWS services from your terminal

- install aws-vault - during one of your next onboarding day you will see  'Netguru way' for managing access and secret AWS key - recommended solution is AWS-vault. You can install it and configure to use aws-cli with your new created aws account via aws-vault instead of traditional aws/credentials file. 
Introduction video how it works

This plugin allows you to keep all your assume roles in Chorme extension - by default AWS allows to keep last 5 roles - sync AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that allows to sync assume roles from time to time - details - install aws-cli - to 'talk' with AWS services from your terminal - install aws-vault - during one of your next onboarding day you will see 'Netguru way' for managing access and secret AWS key - recommended solution is AWS-vault. You can install it and configure to use aws-cli with your new created aws account via aws-vault instead of traditional aws/credentials file. Introduction video how it works

  - sync AWS Extended Switch Roles - Chrome extension that allows to sync assume roles from time to time - details

- install aws-cli - to 'talk' with AWS services from your terminal

- install aws-vault - during one of your next onboarding day you will see  'Netguru way' for managing access and secret AWS key - recommended solution is AWS-vault. You can install it and configure to use aws-cli with your new created aws account via aws-vault instead of traditional aws/credentials file.
